My room was relatively spacious, immaculately clean, with a tv, chest of drawers, two bookshelves, fridge, sink and desk. The bathroom was just down the marble-floored hall, was spotless and was never occupied when I wanted to use it. I was on the 9th floor and had a view across the rooftops of chelsea and further downtown, it was really nice. The bed was super comfortable, slept better here than I have anywhere in a while. In addition to all this, the staff are extremely courteous and friendly, there is free wifi throughout the building, and of course as you'll see from other review, the place is the stuff of pop culture legend and there's lots of cool artwork and a nice atmosphere overall. Honestly, I don't know if my parents (in their 50s) would be happy staying here but for a young person or someone happy to not be staying at the Ritz, it's beyond perfect. The location is fantastic, West Village is a leisurely 15min stroll away, there are loads of places to eat nearby and 2 subway lines are 0.5block away and another line is 1.5blocks away. I was going to the airport at 11pm on the day I checked out, so for $2 was able to leave my bag behind the desk and then could wait with it in the lobby while I waited for the SuperShuttle to take me to Newark. I will definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “The Chelsea - Hip in NY.”
Reviews.Author: sbushell
Reviews.Content: When we stayed in New York a few years ago, we made sure that we were booked into the famous Chelsea Hotel - at least, I tried to make sure, but since they didn't respond to faxes and never sent any confirmation, walking up to the desk in the lobby was disconcerting after the 8 hour flight and taxi from Kennedy Airport. The other disconcerting thing about waiting to see if we did have a suite there, whilst the manager rooted about in a huge ledger, was the pool of blood on the floor right in front of the desk. I never did find out how it got there. Eventually the man on the desk said, "Oh, you're the guy who sent the fax, right?" We were in. The lobby of the Chelsea is littered with sculptures given by famous artists who have stayed there at one point or another, but I noticed that one of them - a man sprawled out on a Chesterfield armchair, dressed in Bermuda shorts and sleeping soundly - looked particularly life-like. Closer inspection revealed that he was a real, sleeping, middle-aged man, and not a sculpture at all. He was in that chair, asleep, when we arrived on the first day, still there when we came back from a restaurant at midnight, and in the same position the next morning, when we went down for breakfast. In fact, he was in that chair for the entire five days and nights that we stayed, and I never saw anyone check to see if he was still alive. Since he never lost his choleric, ruddy complexion, I guess that he was a permanent resident. A very tired resident. I say that we 'went down for breakfast', but - despite a couple of lengthy searches, we never found the breakfast room, and ate at a diner across the road. When we asked where the restaurant was on the first morning, we were told it was on the ground floor in the basement, so we pressed the appropriate button in the lift. When the doors opened, we found ourselves in a cramped laundry room, so we got back into the lift and pressed the button just above the lowest one. When the doors opened again, we were back in the lobby, so we made this short trip a few more times until I decided to forget the lift and search for breakfast using the staircase. As I descended the stairs, I could hear the chinking of crockery, and a babble of muted conversation. I could even - tantalisingly - smell coffee. When I reached the end of the stairs, I found myself in the same laundry room, so I gave up after a few more attempts at finding secret doorways on the stairwell, and we found the cheap diner over the road, not being able to cope with the situation first thing in the morning. The Chelsea is (or was) part permanent residential, and part guest, so the gloomy corridors were always full of the smell of steaming cabbage, etc. as the residents cooked their meals at all times of the day and night. They also play music and watch TV at all times too, so I guess we were not on the same floor that Bob Dylan stays on, when in Town. Our room looked out onto the street, and we could lie in bed, watching the top of the Empire State building gently changing colour at night, and listening to the sirens of police cars and fire engines down below. The rest of the time, we just wandered around Manhattan, soaking up the vibes which I am sure you are familiar with, and which don't need description. We saw a dust cart over-turn on a busy intersection. Since N.Y. dustcarts are about twice the size of London ones, this was quite a sight. The Trump Tower - solid gold and as crass as the owner. Egrets in Central Park. A little piece of Egypt, rebuilt in the museum. A tiny wooden shack uprooted from Sicily, plonked onto the street and surrounded by towering sky-scrapers - home to a quaint Italian restaurant. Vast department stores, packed with Clinique cosmetics at about half the UK prices. I heard last year that the Chelsea was going to have a make-over. Although it probably desperately needed one, I hope they didn't sanitise the life out of it. Did you know that the Chelsea was the first place that the survivors of the Titanic were taken, once they were fished out of the freezing water? It must have seemed like heaven.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, staff and atmosphere!”
Reviews.Author: thd138
Reviews.Content: Had a fantastic week at the chelsea. The whole place has such a nice atmosphere. Clean, cheap and nice rooms. Best location. I will stay here from now on when in NYC.

Reviews.Title: “fantastic atmosphere, great staff, lives up to it's history!”
Reviews.Author: uriahg
Reviews.Content: This was our second stay at the Chelsea. Last time we had a large suite with a street view; this time we were in the back in a really sunny junior suite. We were planning to meet with business clients in our suite, so it was important for us to try to secure a good room. We called and spoke to the day manager, David Elder, who was remarkably helpful and accommodating. He set us up with a really good room (happened to be the residence of Madonna in 1982, as a side note). We were really pleased. This place is fantastic! We've decided to stay here every time. It really feels like you're at a wacky friend's apartment. We've gotten to know some of the permanent residents a little bit, and it feels like home when you run into people in the lobby and hallways. Lots of good food close by, Whole Foods around the corner, and directly between two subway lines. Yes, it's old, and yes, it's quirky; but if that's your thing, the Chelsea is great! Fits our needs perfectly! We love the atmosphere, and we love the feeling. Highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: “More atmosphere than quality”
Reviews.Author: ThomasO4
Reviews.Content: Great place to stay for a weekend in NYC, the location is just perfect if you don´t need to spend your time Mid-Town (which we don´t). The stories and the atmosphere just adds something extra to the hotel, and if it wasn´t for the art and decorations in the corridors, the stories from those who have lived there for years or the ghost stories being told - then this hotel would be a total waste of good money and not at all worth it´s dollars. However, the cram overcomes obvious lacks such as; the lact of a good bathroom, no possibility to control the heat in the room (it´s either sauna hot or freezing) or that there is no possibility to buy drinks or soft drinks in reception. But if you can live with walking to the convenience store, have a scruffy shower and in return get loads of charm, then this is a good choice in NYC.

Reviews.Title: “LOVE it”
Reviews.Author: abkstar
Reviews.Content: Very cool. Hip and very New York. Lots of history. Not to mention, great rates, great rooms, and clean and comfy beds. Great service.

Reviews.Title: “The Best Damn Hotel In The World”
Reviews.Author: Ruby_Pseudo
Reviews.Content: I've been to too many hotels, too many times, and never wanted to write a review on any of them... I've stayed in boutique hotels, corporate hotels, expensive hotels and sweet hotels; hotels where the staff are too keen, hotels where the staff are nowhere to be seen... The Chelsea is unlike all of them. Infamous, decadent, delightful... It is as social as you want it to be, as quiet at you need... That's the beauty of it here, you decide the story of your own stay... If you want to loose yourself in the hotel's heavy history and not speak to anyone for two days, do it here... If you want to drink with artists and actors, ladies and legends, do it here... If you want to walk up and down the beautiful stairs, admiring the hotel's art, do it here... It calls itself a 'rest stop for rare individuals'... Your rest is what you make it... The staff here are impeccable: they are generous, they are gigglers, they are familial and kind. The rooms are personal and pretty, cute and crazy, clean and super comfortable, and each and every one completely different. I have stayed in about six different rooms here, and loved them all. If I could live here, I surely would. No better way to know this city than staying at the Chelsea, business or leisure, with friends or alone. I'd genuinely recommend it to any friend, 'cos it feels like a friend. Niiiiiice.

Reviews.Title: “I LOVE HOTEL CHELSEA”
Reviews.Author: VanityJade
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel because Sid Vicious and Nancy spungen lived at this hotel in the late 70's, even though their room 100 that they stayed in isnt there any more, just the presens of knowing that they stayed there made it all the worth while!!!

Reviews.Title: “A place of legend.”
Reviews.Author: Mintster61
Reviews.Content: I stayed for 7 nights at The Chelsea. It picked itself for me, after Leonard Cohen singing about it in 'Chelsea Hotel No. 2' and knowing some of the things that have gone on there. I flew from Australia to New York for one week only and The Chelsea was a big part of the experience I wanted. I fell in love with the lobby and the little elevators (lifts, in Australia!). The guys staffing the desk were magnificent to me. Couldn't have been more helpful. My room was enormous, I think the bed was king size, I had my own bathroom and kitchen area. And yeah, it was old and not all that shiny, but it was clean and I didn't feel like I was waking up in a box. I could hear the ubiquitous car horns from my room, but only faintly. It only reminded me that I was in the most exciting city I had ever visited. I slept like a baby when I wasn't running around the streets. And the staircase is amazing, and the art is really bright and great. This place has HISTORY, and I bet it would have ghosts if I believed in them. If you want shiny, new and soulless, go to a Holiday Inn or whatever. But the Chelsea is one place I will definitely be going back to. Plus, I just felt cool walking in and out of the place...

Reviews.Title: “Don't Stay At The Chelsea If You Can Help It”
Reviews.Author: jgomezt12
Reviews.Content: The staff is rude, the rooms are dumps - yes, Leonard Cohen slept with J. Joplin there in the 60s..but they still keep the same mattresses, I am sure. It is a piece of history that should be photographed from outside and avoided from inside at all costs. Ah...and if they get your credit card, make sure you check after you leave the hotel if they have not overcharged you. They make "mistakes".

Reviews.Title: “For real?????”
Reviews.Author: Moses54
Reviews.Content: I selected this hotel because it was close to my conference. The price was fair for the area and te website made it appear as if I was robbing them. Well once I got there the computer lost my reservation and I could not make out what the front desk person was saying. I thought she said "you need to share the bathroom with the guest on your floor". I digress, u got to my room and felt as if I was transported to the mid 1970's. The floes and walls were dirty and falling apart, everything in the room was dated. I'm happy to report that I did not have to share the bathroom and I enjoyed my lesson in humility. I would not stay there again under any circumstance. Kudos to anyone who enjoys staying in such an environment.

Reviews.Title: “Charming old hotel filled with character”
Reviews.Author: joe31590
Reviews.Content: Okay. I just got back from my stay at the Chelsea Hotel. Now, I had been reading all about the hotel a year before i even went there, so i was prepared to love it. And I did! Yes, the hotel is old. There are cracks in places, the radiators clang at night, etc. But if you've ever lived in an old house, you'll understand this. For someone who is used to central heating; you may have some trouble sleeping. For our stay, we booked a Suite. That means separate bedroom and private bathroom. Some suites may/may not have a kitchen attached. Ours did not have a kitchen, but it really didn't matter. Also, the room was COLOSSAL. The living room was huge and the ceilings were 12 feet high. In terms of cleanliness, it was very clean, and we had more than enough towels, sheets, blankets, etc. As I said before, it's an old building. But it is not a dirty one. There is no room service. Don't expect it; the hotel is over 100 years old. If you really can't be bothered to walk out into NYC, there's a plethora of chinese, fast food, and chain restaurants in the immediate area that would be happy to deliver. Whenever we returned to the room from a day of walking, we felt as if we were returning to our own apartment. There are plenty of permanent residents. Some were friendly, and some were pretty temperamental. On one occasion, we were going out and we had trouble locking the door. Because the halls are big and long, noise reverberates. The woman across the hall must've heard us trying to lock it, and yelled, "Fix the goddamn door!" We locked the door quietly, and continued to the elevator. Embrace the residents; they make the hotel what it is! Overall, our stay in this hotel made our trip complete, and unforgettable.

Reviews.Title: “wish we could live here!”
Reviews.Author: Hali-shan
Reviews.Content: Alas, they aren't accepting any new tennants. On a quick weekend trip to NYC, my boyfriend and I stayed in a junior suite at the Chelsea Hotel. It is the coolest hotel I've ever stayed. The staff are easily the most helpful and friendly service professionals I've ever experienced (and we're from Canada- land of polite). The room was impeccable and the history of the place makes it worth the stay just to say you were there. Artists in residents have adorned the walls with a legacy of art and photography that rivals many galleries. Seriously, the place is cool as heck. The location is great. You can't request rooms with a street view when you book but if they're available when you check in I recommend trying to get one. The Chelsea Hotel makes you feel like you're living in New York even when you're just visiting.

Reviews.Title: “Living on its history, room was dreadful”
Reviews.Author: alex4420
Reviews.Content: All the character of this arty and 'historic' hotel is in the lobby and corridors - great art, furniture and designs. The rooms are appalling - lumpy mattress, threadbare carpet, putrid wallpaper, heating as hot as a sauna. Our bathroom was OK, but a friend's caused him to move out. If you really want to stay in a room where Patti Smith or Janis Joplin or Dylan Thomas once lived, then this is the hotel for you. Otherwise just come and nose around the lobby.

Reviews.Title: “bad choice--don't make the same one!”
Reviews.Author: egplnt
Reviews.Content: Stayed the other evening. Picked Chelsea based on Frugal Traveler (NY Times) recommendations. Queen with private bath. Decrepit. Room was overheated, about 85 degrees. My husband shut the radiator down. Had to sleep with door to balcony open with the frigid high winds blowing in to cool the room and its few pieces of furniture down so we might be able to sleep. He shut door when we were too cold. Awoke after fitfut sleep to no hot water. No heat either and it was not just because he had to close valve on radiator. He called desk to tell them and received curt response. We quickly packed and left with no shower because of frigid water. At check out received no offer of discount. We had been in our uncomfortable room short time--late check in after show, rock hard bed, very small pillows, "fire trap" with extension cords powering many items in room laying on carpet, much street noise--especially with door to balcony open to cool down room! Finally, after I reminded them we had no heat or hot water and thought they should offer us a discount, they offered $30, not enough to pay all the taxes! Not a friendly staff at all. What was the NY Times thinking? Maybe they stayed somewhere else. Staff ignored us upon early drop off of bags, too busy talking to each other (4 men). Nicest gentleman was the one who was told to take our bags. Thank you, sir.

Reviews.Title: “Unique and Fun”
Reviews.Author: YonderAnnArbor
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed two nights at the famous Hotel Chelsea. Owner/Manager David Elder treated our group with excellent service. The rooms were clean with great interior design and furnishings. This is the hotel for a true New York experience. Great location with easy access to Soho shopping and Chelsea's Art District. Definitely check out the city's new High Line linear park a short walk from the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Dirty, noisy, seedy, overpriced, fleapit, crumbling nightmare of a hotel”
Reviews.Author: tobyhd
Reviews.Content: I have stayed in a lot of hotels/motel/guesthouses/hostels all around the world and in all 50 states in the United States over 2+ decades and this place is one of the worst. For $259 a night, I would have felt better if I'd just been mugged instead. We pre-booked for two nights, arrived at 8pm and were told there was one room left - the Janis Joplin suite - and unfortunately it was "above the nightclub" and would be very noisy until 3am. We were about to look at the room when "room 832" mysteriously became available. It was disgusting - v.small, dusty, threadbare and dilapidated. It's hard to know where to start - there broken tiles all over bathroom, blood stains on the mattress, a discarded pack of cigarettes (presumably from a previous guest) on the corner, chewing gum stuck on the wall, faucets dripping all night and detatched from the wall, toilet didn't flush, aerial not connected to TV, smoke alarm beeping constantly because the battery had run out, unheated bathroom in middle of winter, rusty radiators, holes in walls. We immediately cancelled the second night and went to the Tribeca Grand, which was 5000% better. The lobby of the Chelsea is full of weirdos and there is a slightly threatening, unsafe air about the place. When we were dealing with the guy on the front desk he was constantly on the phone to guests complaining, asking to change rooms and asking to get things fixed. All he could do was fight the fires as best he could and keep apologising. In the morning, the French people in front of me were checking out early because they could not keep their five-month-old son warm or wash him. The only positive thing to say is that the guy on the front desk was polite and there were no rats or corpses in the room If you are drunk, high on drugs or planning to commit suicide then this is the place for you. Otherwise, take a photo of it from the street, check out the bad art in the lobby but do not part with any cash to stay here.

Reviews.Title: “Avoid at all costs”
Reviews.Author: shazzayum
Reviews.Content: Myself and girlfriend had booked a suite for two nights to stay at this hotel to add to the experience of going to see Leonard Cohen in Madison Square Garden. We had read awful reviews about the hotels standard and king rooms so we thought we'd spend extra and go with a suite. We arrived at 12 and was told our room wasn't ready but to come back at 3 and we'd be good to go. During this process, the main porter was barking at staff behind the counter and openly starting an argument with the nice young gent serving us at the time. Extremely unprofessional, but as we would find out, this seemed to be how things are at The Chelsea. When we came back, we were told they had given away all the suites but they could give us a king or our money back (which they were very enthusiastic about). We were very upset about this and we were offered a reduced rate which only turned out to be the rate of the King room they were offering us ($269). We asked to see the room before we accepted and a nicer porter showed us to our room and showed more compassion and understanding than the staff who mucked up our reservation. The room was a dump but we decided that we probably could not get somewhere at the last minute on a Friday night and would have to stay there. The carpets had stains all over it, paint was peeling off the wall and there was a used towel from a previous guest under the bed. At 269 a night, it was incredibly poor value to say the least. After seeing Leonard Cohen, we found a good deal at the Millenium Hilton that night and left the next day. At no stage during our stay were we even offered a basic apology for the mistake and every time we visited the reception counter (4 times) there was another bunch of guests being told there were no rooms for them and they would have to go elsewhere. It looks like whoever is in charge of reservations hasn't a clue what they are doing and it is best to avoid this place. Go in and have a look at the lobby of this hotel but don't step a foot inside one of the rooms.

Reviews.Title: “Rock n' Roll history”
Reviews.Author: twilightmuse
Reviews.Content: We went to NYC In Sept from the 1st-5th. We couldn't pass up the chance to stay at the famous Chelsea Hotel. For those who are unaware of it's history it has been a host to a slew of famous writers, artists and musician from the 60's onwards. People like Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, Bob Dylan, writer Jim Carroll from the Basketball Diaries, Leonard Cohen, the Ramones and most known for the Sid and Nancy debacle ( if your into punk). First off when I was exploring hotels for our trip - NYC is expensive! The Chelsea room rates are extremely reasonable- we paid $135/night with a shared bathroom. Our room came equipped with a sink and cabinet and the bathroom was outside our door down the hall a bit. They also have larger rooms with kitchenettes for families or extended stays and private bathrooms as well. We didn't find there to be an issue with sharing a bathroom as it was only with one other room, and we never ran into any problems with seeing anyone in the halls or having to wait for the room. Our room was right under the famous Chelsea sign as seen in the movie for SId and Nancy, overlooking the street. The room was very clean and the bed was comfy. The hotel itself is a tad run down but more for the option of posterity rather then sluminess. The walls in the hallways are dedicated to portraits of the celebrites that have stayed there and other artists giving it a very funky feel. The larger rooms are each painted up with funky themes as well. There is a big debate right now on renevating the entire hotel and people feel that this would be a great loss to the history of an era and New York itself. I agree. When I think of New York I immediately think of the Chelsea hotel. If your going to the hotel with the intent of anything to do with Sid and Nancy - don't bother. The rooms they used no longer exist ( we asked). But for ghost hunters this hotel definitly has the feel of some presence. The elevator doors opened at random with no one on them or in the hallways, we saw weird shadows on the balcony and there were weird wind rattlings on the upper floors. Spooky but fun. The location is very central to lots of goings on in the city. When we first arrived in the city we spent the first night we stayed up near the museum of modern history and discovered that everything we wanted to see neighbouhood wise was in the lower end of the city. From the Chelsea we walked the neighbouhoods of: Soho, Noho, Greenwich village and the east village. The higher the street number the farther away everything is from Times Square which is 42nd street. The chelsea is at 23rd street and we walked to Time's Square. If I go back to NYC I am definitly staying here again. The staff we pleasant and the hotel was a good story to tell.

Reviews.Title: “Pubic hair was free!!!”
Reviews.Author: camclarissa
Reviews.Content: OMG, what a surprise we had. Myself and three teenagers were in NYC for a school tour at NYU. We were so excited. We arrived at 0130 after a 7 hour drive to find that they had made an error with the reservation and although we had a confirmation showing we had booked two queen size beds, we were going to have to share a bed! Oh well the teenagers said they did not mind spreading out with blankets on the floor. That was until they saw the floor. Also there was no bathroom, we had to share the bathroom with 6 or 7 other rooms! So we were tired, removed the comforter off the bed, and that was when we found the free pubic hair!! We complained of course, but there was nothing we could do! All the other hotels in the area were full! So all four of us piled on top of our own blankets and tried to sleep, we were out of there by 9am and found a hotel at the airport for the rest of our stay. I would not stay there again if they paid me too!!!! The online pics of the hotel really do not prepare you for the horror of a night at the Chelsea!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Hotel for artist...The vibe is amazing... great position”
Reviews.Author: SCHEMA
Reviews.Content: Great position. Hotel has an amazing history and vibe. Hotel is suited to a creator/artist/musican/writer. I would not recommend to others. The hotel is very out there... including the people that live in the hotel. Still seems to be in same condition as 100 years ago. This is the look they are wanting. I like it. It would be great if they offered room service. We had a small room with a shared bathroom. This was fine, it saved us quite on the room price. Price was OK, but NYC is very expensive to stay in!

Reviews.Title: “Wow. Lived up to the hype!”
Reviews.Author: JohnnyRender
Reviews.Content: Do yourself a favor, especially if you are traveling with a larger group, and stay at the infamous Hotel Chelsea. It's reputation as a temporariy/semi-permanent rest stop for Bohemian types (Mark Twain, Bob Dylan, Velvet Underground/Warhol/Factory folks and, yes, Sid Vicious) is legit: You can feel the character in the air. The artwork adorning the 10-story staircase is worth the price of admission alone. If you're looking for Bellagio-style luxury, stay elsewhere. But if you want a day or two in a cool neighborhood in an apartment style flat, the Chelsea is for you! We had a large group and opted to stay in their largest room--the 2-bedroom suite, which has two rooms EACH CONTAINING TWO DOUBLE BEDS! That's right--capacity of 8 people, for not much more money than it costs to get a mediocre room for two elsewhere in Manhattan. Big thumbs up!

Reviews.Title: “Overdose on History and Shabby Elegance.”
Reviews.Author: Versus09
Reviews.Content: First off, this hotel is not for everyone. It's more like an old age home for Studio 54 regulars - if anyone from those days actually survived into old age. I stayed here for one night, which was always a dream of mine, and I walked up the nine flights of stairs to my room, checking out the artwork on the walls, and bumping into a few characters along the way, who were works of art in their own right. My room was small, had a window with NO view, but who cares: NY is best experienced out on the street, rather than in a room. The bedding and bathroom was clean - I paid less than 150 bucks a night, which is a steal in this city, and I could have opted for a cheaper room if I chose to share a bathroom, but I'm not that rustic. The walls looked recently painted, the floors were old parquet, scuffed and worn, and there was a few antique odds and ends strewn about. The others guests looked like they were between acts at some baroque opera house - nearly everyone was in some sort of get-up, whether it be three in the afternoon or three in the morning. The staff were friendly and quick upon check-in and check-out, and a janitor mistook me for a gatecrasher, but I flashed my key in front of him and he held his tongue. This hotel is old, it has its aches and pains, and it has its ghosts. Make this your new favorite hotel when visiting the Rotten Apple.

Reviews.Title: “Unique, Affordable New York Hotel”
Reviews.Author: TheDudeAbides1
Reviews.Content: I mostly chose the Chelsea because of the price, but the history of the place did't hurt the decision either. We enjoyed taking the stairs down from the room and admiring all of the original art adorning the walls. Our room was huge, bigger than apts we have seen in nyc. We didn't know it would have a fridge or stove, but it was nice to have a place to keep our beer and leftovers. The valet parking was cheap for NYC, $1 per hour; and we could come and go as we wanted (but whoe needs a car in new york?).

Reviews.Title: “Great authentic NY hotel with character!”
Reviews.Author: LmacP
Reviews.Content: Loved The Chelsea...Loved the neighborhood! In walking distance from Penn Station it was an easy access hotel. The lobby was fun and arty, the hallways packed with unusual art. Well worn marble stairs. Two elevators worked consistently. The room was just what the two of us needed. We did expect a more elaborate suite since the website boasts really glamorous rooms but I kinda figured it was too good to be true. Nice walk out balcony with old iron railings. Stucco walls were kinda dingy feeling but it added to the authentic feel. Clean sheets, clean towels, drank the water right out of the faucet with no problems. Great location, Deli on the corner sucked though so don't waste your time. Go to Murray's Bagels instead for breakfast. Pizza place on the block was great and the Tai place across the street was cheap and pretty good. Highline Park just a quick jaunt away with great views of Chelsea Piers. Service at the hotel was a little slow when busy but the door men are quick to ask you for your key before letting you up so that no randoms are walking through the halls. Floors in our room could have used vaccuming and the fixtures were rustic but if you have ever lived in NYC you know the feel. It felt like we were a part of history and the price was great...$169 for a week night and $179 for weekend. Watch out for those taxes though...OUCH!

Reviews.Title: “Strange Guests, but loved it anyway!”
Reviews.Author: CaramelSmoothie
Reviews.Content: We ran into some strange people in the lobby area of the hotel. Other than that, our stay was relaxing and non-eventful. Front desk staff is super nice and helpful, housekeeping is efficient and nice. Location is great! Just a 10 to 15 walk to Times Square and the Empire State building. We had a room with a kitchenette (fridge, stove, oven, sink, cabinets) which was awesome! Prices are very reasonable. This will always be my place to stay when I come to New York.

Reviews.Title: “Good choice with rock and roll history”
Reviews.Author: fussytraveleruk
Reviews.Content: We arrived at the Chelsea Hotel after a terrible experience at the Jane hotel. We didn't have reservations and weren't sure what to expect. The gents at the front desk got us into a room for $189 per night. The Chelsea is an old apartment building with many eccentric residents. The building certainly does not feel like a traditional hotel, with artwork and residents around. But the room was clean and we had a balcony overlooking the street and the famous neon sign. We are traveling the USA on a summer concert tour and we are all so happy to have experienced the home of Janis Joplin and Bob Dylan. It ended up being a highlight of our trip and

Reviews.Title: “Even better than I imagined! Why did I even trust the bad reviews?”
Reviews.Author: WeeElf
Reviews.Content: It's always been a dream of mine to stay at the Hotel Chelsea. Finally the occasion came up, a 4 night weekend in New York. I wasn't sure what to expect, as I'm rather picky when it comes to hotels (I need a good bed and a clean bathroom), and the official website doesn't show much. So I went on tripadvisor and checked the review and pictures, and the bad reviews scared me a little. What a mistake. Instead of trusting my guts and booking 4 nights, I only booked one night and the rest at the Grand Hyatt through Priceline (price for a night there was the same as one at the Chelsea). I arrived early (around noon), it was too early to check in but they took care of my luggages so I could be free to walk around for a couple of hours. Then was time to check in. I was anxious about the room, expecting a really small room (I booked a double bed with kitchen, the second cheapest, still, $160), but it turned out the room was amazing. Very large, beautiful, lots of light. Exactly like I imagined, only better. It had a gorgeous fireplace, two windows, high ceillings, a huge bed, a closet. Old furnitures that were exactly what to expect in this hotel (they fit perfectly), I also loved the bathroom. I just wanted to move there! I will for sure always come back, and not just for one night... I was really sad to leave, and even sadder when I saw the room at the Hyatt (supposedly 4 stars, I expected something great), tiny, dark, with unfriendly staff. Terrible stay there. It was also a pleasure to walk around and look at the art on every floor. The lobby was very lively, great people, great staff (except I wish they'd have answered my question! I asked how many rooms exactly were in the hotel, an information I can't imagine secret, and he was very vague, he wouldn't tell me the exact number nor how many residents they have, and that upset me a bit because it mattered to me to know :P). So I truly recommend the Chelsea for people who know the Hotel, and who are looking for a bohemian, original, unique vibe.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome place to stay - Great location and decent price.”
Reviews.Author: iwaswayoff
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 8 nights. The room was large with high ceilings, old polished floor boards, small kitchenette and walk in wardrobe which is great for keeping the mess out of the living space. The walls need a paint but it is clean with fluffy white fresh towels. Best of all it had a balcony to watch the world go by. Location is fantastic, loads of restaurants and shops around and 2 subway lines either side of the building. The staff were nice and helpful. We ran into a famous Australian Band in the elevator. If you want Brand new and shiny, this is not the place for you. But if character and convinience is your thing then this is the place to stay in New York.

Reviews.Title: “The most amazing place”
Reviews.Author: camilla197
Reviews.Content: If you aren't the kind of person who dies a little bit inside when you stay at a Holiday Inn then this may not be the place for you. Before I arrived I was worried about how clean the place would be but our stay was magnificent. The room was shabby - the bathroom door didn't close properly, my boyfriend had to reprogram the television to make it work, peeling enamel in the bath etc - but none of that mattered. The room and the hotel itself has such a great atmosphere and the history and location are without peer. The staff were great - very professional but not devoid of personality or opinion. The sheets and towels were clean and changed daily & the bathroom was scrubbed everyday. The Chelsea Savoy four doors down is a perfectly beige hotel - clean, consistent and without personality. The Hotel Chelsea makes you feel like you are in on something special - I've never felt inclined to swagger before but every time I walked up to the doors, I felt a little like a rockstar. I can't wait to return - it felt like home.

Reviews.Title: “not for everyone...”
Reviews.Author: Panic_in_Detroit
Reviews.Content: Ok, fair enough, we had chosen the cheapest rooms with shared bathroom and we got the cheapest and dirtiest room you can imagine. In the end you have to decide for yourself if the incredibly cool staff and the notorious location weigh up these nightmare rooms with filthy washbowls, never polished mirrors and overused beds. In the end the high room rate makes me think that this hotel wasn't worth staying in. Yet nights to remember...

Reviews.Title: “CAREFULL Don't book before seeing the room you might get because, our room was a dump”
Reviews.Author: mtl001
Reviews.Content: Got there with my wife and my 2 girls (8-13). The room was not ready yet a 3:45pm even if the check in is a 3pm. But don't worry they take care of your car, check you in, than show you the room. For sure it didn't match the pictures from their web site. It was so discusting that my 8 yr ask me if she could seat on the chair in the room. We ask for another room but off course they didn't have any available even if the key holder was full...long story short it cost me 1 night to cancel even if we didn't spent 5 min in. Plus 20$ for 30 min valet parking. We ended up at the Savoy Chelsea Hotel at 30% cheaper, with small breakfast incl. and 10000% cleaner. Even the clerk at this hotel was not supprise to see us coming from the previous one...seem to be usual thing. So if you really want to stay there don't book online and don't check in before seeing the room.

Reviews.Title: “So worth it!”
Reviews.Author: happydaysOntario
Reviews.Content: This hotel is an icon, but some of the reviews have been less then kind. I had to check it out and convinced my husband to give it a shot. We both LOVED it. Character and really great staff! Thanks Melissa!!!!! Ideal location and a great trip. Thanks Chelsea!

Reviews.Title: “A Cultural Treasure that MUST be experienced Please don't change it.”
Reviews.Author: travelerseattle
Reviews.Content: Much has been written about the Chelsea Hotel but nothing compares with the actual experience. There is something magic about it. The art and history are very rich and the building is beautiful. I have visited the hotel lobby before and finally got to stay. We can't quit talking about our experiences there and want to return soon. We want to especially thank Jerry and the rest of the staff. They made our stay memorable and interesting. The Chelsea Hotel represents those who have gone before and, hopefully, those still to follow. We live in Seattle and there was an article in our local paper about the changes at the Chelsea. It is our hope that the tradition of the Hotel does not change. Also don't miss the El Quixote next door. We were fortunate to meet a long term artist tenant of the Chelsea there. Hope to see you again soon.

Reviews.Title: “Low-Key Getaway”
Reviews.Author: aroundtworld
Reviews.Content: I regret not visiting the Hotel Chelsea when it was more of a haven to artists. Then again, a room might not have been available and I would not have felt as safe. As it is, there are still numerous residents in the hotel to lend it charm and artwork line the hallways and lobby. Our room was clean and nicely decorated for the small size. There was no cable TV. The service was dependable and they catered to our requests for more towels, soap, a hairdryer, an extra two days stay and watched our luggage after check out. If we were demanding guests, they didn't make us feel like it. I highly recommend reading a little history on the place before you go. Reflecting on the great artists that passed through its doors and revering what the hotel stands for will make it worthwhile.

Reviews.Title: “Unique - a landmark worth the hype!”
Reviews.Author: paatelainen
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the Chelsea for four nights at the end of May and found it to be a fantastic experience. The area directly around the hotel was a little lifeless but further into Chelsea or over in the flatiron district there were some great places. The hotel itself is not exactly plush but it has so much character. There is art everywhere and reminders of the hotel's fantastic history. The door staff, porters and concierges were absolutely fantastic, friendly and funny and really really helpful. Best service I've had anywhere in a long time. We asked to change to a twin room which was organised straight away and all the staff could not have been more helpful. The residents gave the place a lot of character as well and it was a very interesting experience! I would definitely recommend the Chelsea to anyone searching for a bit of culture.

Reviews.Title: “Unbelievable - Stayed one night and this was one night to many.”
Reviews.Author: ArneOnAJourney
Reviews.Content: To say i was disappointed with the accommodation and facilities is an understatement. The room was seriously shabby; worn carpets, wallpaper pealing off the wall in places, broken window blind, damaged wall fittings, the door to the room appeared to have been forced several times and badly repaired, extremely worn bathroom fittings, problems with the electrical sockets, electrical cables exposed, no internet access in room. Arrived in the evening after a flight from Europe; checked out first thing in the morning and spent the rest of my trip to New York elsewhere. The bed linen and towels were clean otherwise i would have checked out immediately. I did not feel safe in the few hours I spent in the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Don't miss out on staying here”
Reviews.Author: jellcup
Reviews.Content: We loved our stay at the Chelsea. It was liking staying in a gallery for a night. We wondered around enjoying the art covering walls and the general ambienance of the hotel. A piece of New York's cultural histrory. The room we had included a kitchenette and bathroom, and although honestly the furniture and decor looked old and cheap, it all suited feel of the hotel and was confortable enough. We loved our windows opening on to a balconette with a great view of the hotel's classic neon sign. The bakery on the corner was fantastic and the thai further down is also highly recommened.

Reviews.Title: “Staying at the Chealsea really made our trip”
Reviews.Author: zobot
Reviews.Content: It's set in a great area. We were in New York visiting my brother who lives in Williamsburg and going to some friends' art shows and generally hanging out. We were right near all the art galleries and found some great little pubs and restaurants nearby. But it was the hotel that mad the trip. Great, characterful staff, amazing lobby, very clean and grand (if a bit rough around the edges in a charming way) room with lovey big windows and balcony. A highlight of our stay has to be the mature lady in a silver suit in the lobby with her 4 matching dogs. A wonderful, eccentric and romantic place to be. Perfect. I will DEFINTELY stay when i'm next in NYC.

Reviews.Title: “Chelsea--Not For Everyone, But It Doesn't Claim to Be”
Reviews.Author: JzeroT1937
Reviews.Content: "Hotel Chelsea: NYC: A Rest Stop for Rare Individuals"--the slogan for the Hotel Chelsea as expressed by the soap bar I stole from my room. The Chelsea is historical; it's a cultural landmark. Everyone from Mark Twain to Sid Vicious has stayed here, and its gained a reputation with the underground crowd as a sort of cultural Mecca. The problem with this, of course, is that its gained mainstream popularity through word of mouth, which causes many people to presume it to be some sort of luxurious, gentrified resort. Don't get me wrong; I found this place to be very relaxing and comfortable. But luxurious, it ain't. I stayed in a single shared bathroom on the third floor with a balcony right next to the Chelsea Hotel sign--room 319. It was enormous, had a queen bed and decent TV, two nightstands and lamps, a worktable, and a closet. By Manhattan standards, the room was enormous. It was also very quiet. There was also the scummy element. The headboard had water stains on it and mirror large rust-marks. The turnover service took my sheets and placed them in a way that didn't really replicate the way they were when I came in, but did good enough. The shared bathroom was not a problem--it was shared amongst three rooms, but I never found myself without a pot at an inconvenient moment. I came here from The Big Apple Hostel in Times Square, which I found to be inhospitable. I've been a hostel traveler for the last several years of my life; I'm not sure if I'm simply outgrowing the ability to cope with hostel standards or if the Big Apple was simply too awful, but I had to switch to a hotel. I figured while I was here, I might as well make it a memorable switch. Originally I was going to book the Waldorf-Astoria--the other NYC hotel I fantasize about--but found it overbooked. The Chelsea it was. Do I regret the decision? Not one bit! Two nights of fabulous sleep, great staff, and an unbelievable artistic, bohemian air about the place. It's not for everyone. Don't expect grandiose amenities and pristine, newly remodeled furniture; that's not what the Chelsea's about. If you want someplace nice, check the Waldorf. If you want culture, artistic individuals, and a place to sleep, this is the place for you. Also, take the ride to the top of the building and sneak out on the roof for some awesome photos. The door has a sign that says "Absolutely no roof access for hotel guests" but this can be by-passed through the simple device of a book placed between the door and doorframe. Had a great time. Would definitely recommend!

Reviews.Title: “don't change it- great atmosphere.”
Reviews.Author: bernadetteCo_donegal
Reviews.Content: stayed for 2 nights during march at the end of our trip to ny.we loved it.found the staff great-quirky and good sense of humour.our room had beautiful curtains and bedspread-old lovely fabric.loved the building, paintings on the stairs and all the halls.the place has a special character and lovely people knocking about it. definately a hotel for artists to enjoy.not a hotel for some looking for conference type accomadation.our room was clean. lots of towels. fridge. tv and brilliant location, near to all the chelsea art galleries.[we met patti smith at her opening exhibition a few streets away]. also the hotel is near subway that takes you to the airport and also near the bus station that will take you to woodstock. and lastly a great spanish cocktail bar and restaurant next door that has the best crab claws i've tasted in a long time.we were happy lovers!

Reviews.Title: “I guess you could say that my room had historic trash”
Reviews.Author: synthdoll
Reviews.Content: The only reason why I am giving this a two is because the location hotel is nice, I love the artwork displayed in the hallway, it's historic value and I believe that some of the rooms are beautiful. However, my room, 722 needed help. The room itself is beautifully decorated, it is a room with pink furnishings and a black -white kitchen. Although it really needs an update since there was paint was peeling, tiles on the floor were missing, the wood from the floor was missing and the material in the room looked seriously worn. I tried to let that get to me, but as I unpacked my bags and explored further, I noticed how many issues my room had. Along with those issues, here are the other issues I didn't expect from the hotel: Door would not lock or shut Noticed crumpled cookies from the previous dwellers The fireplace had a cup filled with used cigarettes No towels when I initially walked into the wash closet A beer was left in my fridge (Even though my friend thought it was sent from God LOL this was still really disturbing) The pink comforter was seriously worn I noticed some random blonde hairs as well (I'm a red head and my friend has pink hair - no way that came from us) The sofa that was in the room also had holes in its material No internet I knew that the room was "made up" since the bed was done and everything else looked in place.... but this is neglect. Cleanliness is important to me and this really bugged me. We called the front desk and addressed my issues, they said someone would come up. Me and my friend walked out for a bit, when we came back we saw that the bed was redone and we had one extra towel. Trash was not picked up and we still had an issue with the door. I called back and 20mis later we hear someone shutting our door. I was pretty upset, this was supposed to be my escape with her and I ended up wanting to escape. Even though the room was extremely worn, it was seriously the most beautifully designed I have ever seen (note, this is kinda biased since I am crazy about the color pink lol) it was such a pity to see that a few things destroyed it.

Reviews.Title: “Don't let the haters scare you...”
Reviews.Author: SherpaDan
Reviews.Content: I arrived Friday, March 6th at the front door of the Chelsea, with a bit of weary optimism. I had peeked inside the lobby and snuck up the stairs to gawk at the art before but had never actually spent the night. Some of the drastic comments I have seen posted here almost got the best of me, but I put my curiosity in control and drove down from Boston for the weekend of play. I had priced the local garages online for what a weekend stay would cost me, $150.00 for three days (no in and out privileges) seemed about the norm. I was very pleased to find out the Chelsea has some deal with a local garage, where a valet will pick your car up when you check in and drop it back off when you check out….. for 25.00 a day. That’s pretty cheap. The front desk staff was both helpful and inattentive, a combo that worked just fine. This is not a five star Hotel, don’t come here expecting to be pampered, but don’t thinking the staff are villains either. If the guy was busy, I waited, and waited, but when he did help me he was very helpful giving me ideas of what to do in the area, stories about the hotel … and residents. I booked a one bedroom for 209.00 a night. I was terrified of trying the shared bath for 89.00. I booked room 502 a room that had been rented to a resident until about 6 months ago. IT WAS HUGE. The room had been recently painted (white) and had the wood floors just refinished, but other than that, it was the bare bone of what I had expected. The bed itself was really hard to sleep on but surprisingly clean. The bathroom was spotless. For the most part, everything is old with 100 years plus of character. You come here to absorb the history, talk to the other guests and, if you’re lucky, a resident that doesn’t feel bothered by your presence. The Chelsea is an acquired taste, a gourmet one at that.

Reviews.Title: “There's something about the Chelsea...”
Reviews.Author: Inkblotspot
Reviews.Content: I couldnt go to NYC and not stay at the Chelsea...being a Bob Dylan fan, I'd heard about its charm and pull and history, so it was a must-do on my itinerary. I'm very glad we went, and my partner and I enjoyed our stay...but I fear this was more to do with our new found love of New York than the hotel itself. When we arrived we were told that we did not have a booking, even though we had a printed confirmation and had paid for the two nights via the Chelsea's official website. It took two very poor receptionists about 30 minute to straighten out the mix up - though most of that time was spent with them ignoring us, talking amongst themselves or serving other people who had arrived after we had. Eventually we were shown up to our room, which was very, very basic. It had a view of a run down apartment block next door, and a bathroom that was so small only a yoga instructor could make their way around it. Despite this, my boyfriend and I did enjoy our time at the Chelsea. It was close to the subway and some great bars, and once we didnt have to deal with the staff anymore, it served as a great base.

Reviews.Title: “Greatest hotel in the World”
Reviews.Author: spanishjohn
Reviews.Content: The Chelsea is obviously very famous for those who have stayed here and those who have died there. As other reviews testify its not renowned for being a great hotel. Don't stay here of you don't want to meet eccentric people, don't stay if clanking heating annoys you and don't stay if you want a hermetically sealed, hypoallergeinc Philippe Starck experience. This place reeks of atmosphere (amongst other things) which is worth the room rate 3 times over. In reality the room I stayed in was quite perfect, restored but not stripped of all heritage. Stay and enjoy it for being the best hotel in the world, if not go to a Marriott and knock yourself out.

Reviews.Title: “You get what you pay for - and it can be marvellous!”
Reviews.Author: EveManchester
Reviews.Content: We read the reviews, but still decided it was 'for us' - largely because my partner's grandmother lived at the Chelsea in the 60s... and we decided to pay top dollar (ie, nearly $300 per night) for a good room. And very very good room it was too. Room 715, if someone wants a recommendation! Enormous for most cities, let alone NYC. Kitchenette with fridge / hob / microwave and cupboard space, huge balcony with french windows opening onto it, hardwood floors, walk-in closet, flat-screen tv, vast bathroom with fresh new tiling and mirrored cabinet, and one of the most comfortable hotel beds I've slept on. When we checked in, the friendly desk guy said it was one of their most recently refurbed rooms - and it showed. So, ask for a refurbed room, and be prepared to pay for it is my advice. Sure, the rooms for $99 look pretty crummy – but $99 in NYC? In Chelsea? What on earth do you expect? As for the desk staff, I treated them with respect and found most of them responded to it well (some were tougher nuts to crack, admittedly). The maids, ditto. I smiled, and they smiled back. Yes, they didn’t replace our shampoo & soap, so I asked. Nicely. And got an armful (Yay for souvenirs!). Just as others have said, they didn’t change the bedsheets in 5 days (probably would have if I’d asked but we aren’t that grubby…) BUT we did get more clean fluffy white towels than you can shake a stick at. Our room was at the front of the hotel, and duh, surprise, it was noisy. For those who moan about NYC being noisy – go stay in a forest. It’s a city, for crying out loud! (I travel everywhere with earplugs). It was worth the noise to stand on the lovely balcony every night, looking up West 23rd Street at the flickering lights and taxis whizzing past. And what an amazing ambience. The art, the oddballs, the straggly residents, the kind old ladies who spoke to me in the lobby, and oh, that astounding staircase!

Reviews.Title: “what an experience”
Reviews.Author: weenikkib
Reviews.Content: i can not stress enough just how much i enjoyed this hotel. it is very comfortable, with wonderful history and a nice location. i read all the reviews of this hotel before my visit ans was starting to get a little nervous. what a pleasent surprise we had. we stayed there for 6 nights and booked a standard room. inside this we had a double bed, private bathroom, cooker, fridge, sofa, table and chairs and widescreen tv. i was shocked by the size and sheer comfort of this hotel. it certainly has a homely feel to it. i would certainly book again for this hotel and will be for my next visit. wonderful art throughout the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Glorious”
Reviews.Author: Abesaywhat
Reviews.Content: Having read the reviews I was a little apprehensive, which was offset by being able to tell people where I was going to stay, which in turn was offset by the total lack of any recognition on their faces. The first time you enter the hotel don't just rush to the desk, take a moment and look around, its only a small lobby and its elegance has faded, but just look. Don't forget to look up. If you seek a homogeneous room in a clinical hotel then do not stay here. When you step out of the lift you will want to go no further. There is a dilapidated feel to the hallways - its gone beyond faded elegance - but then you see the artwork and begin to absorb the spirit of the place The staff were great, not the 'yes sir, no sir, 3 bags full sir' type of hotel staff, they were real people, you could talk to them, and anything we asked for was done - immediately. The porter was a guy called Angel - softly spoken and aptly named. The room was stunning - totally at odds with the descriptions I'd read. As to the noise - we could hear classical music being listened to and played quite loudly, but only when we were on the landing, not in the room, as to the traffic - well you are in Manhattan and you can only block out so much noise. We had to listen for noise, it most defintely did not keep us awake. You will encounter the locals, ranging from people looking like bag ladies, to another couple who could have been Ramones - he answered to Joey, and I think she was called Sheena.....they just add to the character of the place. I would probably try and avoid a room at the front of the hotel and on a low floor - there is a club playing dance music underneath. If you like the hotel, you probably won't like the club, but check out the bar a few doors down, East of Eighth. I could easily have stayed up for days in the Chelsea Hotel , but could never have written Sad Eyed Lady of the Lowlands.

Reviews.Title: “Rude Staff Noisy Hotel Horrible Experience !!”
Reviews.Author: area51alien
Reviews.Content: Chelsea hotel is supposedly a great hotel with alot of history. the hotel was a total dump, dirty and the rudest most unfriendly staff with attitude ive ever encountered. they didnt leave us washclothes or extra towels or soap and shampoo. wheni called downstairs to get it was told they items were "locked up" and couldnt be gotten till next day. the next day they still didnt bring it. completely horrifying to pay $300 a night for a hotel and you cant get a wash cloth or a sample of shampoo. rudest most unfriendly staff, the guys at the desk were terrible. never hello, never a smile, so unfriendly completely put us in a bad mood and didnt want to be there. so noisy absolutley IMPOSSIBLE to sleep every night. absolutley the most disgusting horrifying hotel ever in the whole world ive ever been to.

Reviews.Title: “Nostalgic: Yes. But totally run down, filthy and overpriced”
Reviews.Author: JoopUitendaal
Reviews.Content: The Chelsea Hotel was recommended to me by a friend. Reading about its history made me very excited to book a room there for 5 nights - price per night $400 including taxes. Entering the lobby actually matched my expectations (a bit cheeky to have to pay the full charge of 5 nights upfront). But once up in my room and I already regretted having to stay there. It was very obvious that no maintenance had taken place during the last 30 years or so. Wires all across the floors and the ceiling, dirty furniture, smelly closets, just disgusting. Only very positive thing about the hotel is its location - couldn't be better in the heart of the Chelsea district with cool restaurant, bars and clubs and good shopping in walking distance. But overall conclusion - stay away from the Chelsea Hotel. There are plenty of other nice places to stay in the Chelsea district.

Reviews.Title: “Destination in itself!”
Reviews.Author: Brigahan
Reviews.Content: We were headed to NYC w/ some good friends who booked the hotel. We checked out the hotel's website, and thought it looked great--and we liked the price and location, too. Then I started reading all of these reviews and was almost dreading our arrival! Well, the hotel was great. We had a recently-renovated very large two BR suite on the 6th floor. Everything in our suite was pristine. Two beautiful baths, two brand new kitchenettes. Two flat-screen TVs and two Bose iPod sound docks. A handsome, artfully decorated parlor with a stunning fireplace. New flooring, new area rugs. Great light fixtures, too. A balcony w/ floor to ceiling glass-paned doors. Comfy beds and clean, fresh linens. Very nice, helpful staff. The lobby is cool and the art-lined stairway is entertaining. The street is very noisy, but tolerable. The building is old and fairly run down and I'm sure there are crappy rooms, but from what I can tell, the rooms are being renovated slowly. Our suite was $599 per night, which is a good deal for 4 people. So, I'd recommend only staying there if you get a renovated room and are OK with some street noise (the hotel guests and residents were not loud at all). All in all, it was a great stay for us!

Reviews.Title: “A living legend”
Reviews.Author: Fudge03
Reviews.Content: Well, it's the Chelsea, and to be honest it was exactly what I expected, good and bad. It was just a single night stay, as we passed through New York on the way home, and I have to admit it gave me a tremendous buzz to walk in through those hallowed portals, with their lists of people who had lived and died here, and march up to the desk saying "I have a reservation". The room was tiny, and we had a "semi-private" - i.e. shared - bathroom which was two corridors away. The room also came with retro egg-shaped chair and complementary dead cockroach. The other downside was that the desk staff only existed to check you in and out - any requests for help, from advice on internet access to taxi-bookings, fell on deaf ears. And yet, and yet, it is great to stay in a living legend. The selection of art down the stairs, the notices, the personalised doors, etc. etc. were a joy to behold. Highly recommended - but for a short stay!

Reviews.Title: “A must stay...but just a night...not for everyone”
Reviews.Author: sckobie
Reviews.Content: Just stayed a the Hotel Chelsea, i am an ex NY-er and was always intrigued by the hotel, now that I travel on business I figured I would give it a try. You can not help but feel the soul of this place being pushed down your throat upon entering, if you can't feel that don't stay here, if you can you will thoroughly enjoy. I look at a hotel as a place to sleep, meet people, take a shower and leave- if you are looking for primping and pampering this is not your gig. I arrived and was given a room in the back on the first floor- it was purple and dark and not good energy, I called and asked for a room on 23rd street that may be a bit brighter, Room 915 was fine, it is a queen size bed, nice big window, decent furniture (as I was working in the room during my stay. Yes the walls are scuffed, the carpet ancient, the windows dirty, the bathroom, aged but not dirty. If you have stayed at a freinds house that is old and messy it is probably not that different. The place is 100+ years old and has never been remodeled- which is part of the whole deal. There are certain things in the universe that you can only find in NYC and the Hotel Chelsea is one of these gems- you can easily walk to the village and it is really nicely located for subways, etc. I met up with some old freinds in the Hotel and we had a great time enjoying the Hotel before heading out for some food. It was quiet, I slept great, was awakened at 4 AM - it felt like (or I had a mental image of) someone was handing me a glow in the dark frisbee) but got right back to sleep- after reading of the hauntings, etc maybe I had an overactive imagination- but this building is freindly and welcoming. If you want to be a bit adventurous it should not be missed.

Reviews.Title: “Glad I did it, but never again”
Reviews.Author: meena482
Reviews.Content: My husband is a musician, need I say more? We stayed at the Chelsea Hotel, because he wanted the experience of staying where so many ledgens have lived and died. Alot of work has been put into the lobby and stair cases, but our room was not so lucky. It was small, which I can deal with- it is New York after all. The sheets were clean when we arrived, but they were not changed at all during our five nights there (towels were though). The carpet was what bugged me the most. In fact, an hour after we arrived I went and bought flip-flops to wear while in the room. It was strained, and was in desparate need of replacing. The bathroom was reasonably clean, but could have used a refresher. Robert at the front desk was extremely friendly and helpful. A few of the other people at the desk were less so. My husband could over look all the cleanliness issues, because he was so excited to be staying there. I suggest that if you aren't emotionally attached to the building already, do not stay there. I'm glad my husband's curiousity was satisfied, but I have already told him we are never staying there again!

Reviews.Title: “Sad, tired and tragic.”
Reviews.Author: amycakes86
Reviews.Content: Having read many reviews before i got to the hotel, i was prepared for the worst, and my stay went pretty much as expected. Our room was on the first floor looking out onto 23rd street, directly above a club which did not close until 4am. There was no air con, and just an insufficient ceiling fan which at one point actually broke and landed on the bed, narrowly missing my partner and i. The fridge was extremely noisy, and the 2 windows were secured only by a couple of flimsy latches. Not a great deal of security considering we shared our balcony with the rest of the 1st floor. The bed was so rickety it wobbled every time you made the slightest move, and with regards to the bathoom, well lets just say that i chose to wear flip flops in the shower. On our first morning there the bath didn't even drain the water away (though this myseriously only happened once). The staff were friendly, but it took us over 2 hours to get a replacement fan when ours broke. The maids are also quite impatient, and many of them don't speak fluent English, which was something of a problem when we had maintenance issues. The room was generally quite shabby, but the hotel does have it's endearing qualities. For example, the hallways, staircase and lobby do have a genuine aura, and as a historian i enjoyed looking at the different layers of history which are so visible all over the hotel (the art deco bath tub, the cast iron stair case etc). However, i was not paying to stay in the hallway or the lobby. I can't help but feel a bit sorry for this grand old dame of a hotel, as it's clearly been neglected as the former proprietor, Stanley Bard, has desperately tried to cling on to it's infamous past. The thing is, the history can still be preserved and celebrated without guests and residents alike having to literally live in the caked on scum of yesteryear. The history of this hotel is definately notorious enough to survive a refurb! And might i add that, although this place is apparently a mecca for tortured artists, judging by some of the work lining the hallways some of them should really stop trying to live the dream.

Reviews.Title: “Disgusting Place”
Reviews.Author: MemphisElvis
Reviews.Content: My mother and I stayed at the Chelsea over the weekend. We chose it on recommendation of my very artsy younger sister. Also the location is fantastic to everything we wanted to do. We also heard that several rooms were haunted and thought it would be fun to try. Well, the only thing that haunted our room was the lingering smell of urine which has now permeated all my clothes. I have washed them twice since I got home and I still smell the Chelsea Hotel. The hallways are fiulled with art left by residents and visitors. Our floor was covered with art of towering infernos and evil spectors. Not very welcoming! The room (#705) was incredibly shabby. Wood floors were worn and tiles around the fireplace were broken/missing. The bathtub paint was peeling and would fill up to my calves when I showered. Disgusting. The window locks were broken and we once found our neighbor looking into our room through the balcony window. The bedspreads were worn and ripped in spots. I woudn't dare shine a black light on them! I overheard another guest complain of the hairs she found in her bed. There were cigarette burns in the furniture. The A/C was functional but very loud. The residents (one of whom lived next door) played his stereo loudly from 2 AM on every night. Unless you are a flamboyant, artsy type hoping to channel the artistic vibe of the place, do not consider staying here.

Reviews.Author: popartpooch
Reviews.Content: My mother and I stayed at the Chelsea over the weekend. We chose it on recommendation of my very artsy younger sister. Also the location is fantastic to everything we wanted to do. We also heard that several rooms were haunted and thought it would be fun to try. Well, the only thing that haunted our room was the lingering smell of urine which has now permeated all my clothes.
